Headline.Para: Ethnic tensions may flare as Kalimantan polls loom

LeadPara.Para: History of violence, Islamist groups gaining ground, spark fears over gubernatorial race
West Kalimantan is the ancestral home of the Dayak, a tribal people who have thrived in the hinterland of Borneo for centuries.

TailParas.Para: Today, they live alongside the Bugis, Chinese, Javanese, Madurese and Malays, in one of Indonesia's most diverse provinces.
A big anomaly is that just 59 per cent of West Kalimantan's 4.5 million people are Muslims, compared with almost 90 per cent nationally.
About half of its total population also identify themselves as Dayaks, many of whom are Christians or followers of indigenous beliefs.

The central government has expressed fears that identity politics will rear its ugly head during upcoming elections, when voters pick their next governor from a slate comprising the popular Dayak-Christian pairing of Karolin Margret Natasa and Suryadman Gidot and their rivals, who include a duo of Muslim candidates.

Observers have noted that the Islamist movement behind the divisive elections in Jakarta - which led to the ouster of Chinese-Christian politician Basuki Tjahaja Purnama as governor last year - has traversed the Java Sea and stoked similar tensions in West Kalimantan.

"Their concern is rooted in the history of ethnic violence (and) recent tensions between Dayak and Malay ethnic groups stemming from the national fallout of a bitter campaign for Jakarta governor," said political analyst Deka Anwar from the Jakarta-based Institute for Policy Analysis of Conflict (Ipac).

He added that Islamist activists from the Aksi 212 movement - named after the rally held on Dec 2, 2016, to topple Basuki - may try to influence the West Kalimantan election by propagating, as they did in Jakarta, that Muslims can vote only for Muslim candidates.
CANDIDATES RESPONSIBLE FOR PEACE
It will be up to the candidates to ensure that the polarisation left over from the anti-Ahok campaign does not produce communal clashes.

MR DEKA ANWAR, a political analyst from the Jakarta-based Institute for Policy Analysis of Conflict, referring to the divisive elections in Jakarta which led to the ouster of Chinese-Christian politician Basuki Tjahaja Purnama, nicknamed Ahok, as governor last year.

Aksi 212 is synonymous with the Islamic Defenders Front (FPI), a hardline group that took to the streets in the capital during the election campaign to call for the arrest of Basuki for insulting Islam.
The eventual imprisonment of the former Jakarta governor - better known as Ahok - for blasphemy has emboldened the FPI to attempt a repeat in West Kalimantan.

There have also been worries that in the aftermath of the anti-Ahok campaign, predominantly Muslim Malays were now identifying more with groups such as the FPI, and finding allies among non-Dayak Muslim migrants, increasing the potential for tensions to escalate, Mr Deka's study for Ipac has found.
However, hardline groups trying to establish a foothold in Kalimantan risk the wrath of the Dayak, who have always been intolerant of religiosity in their homeland.
The FPI has tried in recent years but failed at least twice.

In February 2012, FPI leaders who were planning to set up a local branch in Central Kalimantan were blocked at the airport and told to leave the province by the Dayak, who were once feared by early explorers as savage headhunters.
Last May, another FPI group, buoyed by the downfall of Basuki, arrived at the airport in the provincial capital Pontianak, only to be put off by a boisterous mob of Dayaks.

The upcoming gubernatorial election to be held on June 27 is part of regional polls throughout the vast archipelago to select governors in 17 provinces, mayors in 39 cities and heads of 115 regencies.

The elections will also tee up the national polls on April 17 next year, when Indonesians will, for the first time, cast their votes for their president and their parliamentary representatives on the same day.
While the focus has largely been on the polls in Java because of its larger voter base, the West Kalimantan gubernatorial race could emerge as a potential flashpoint.

Many have pointed to last year's mayoral election in Singkawang - a city in West Kalimantan with a large Chinese community - during which a local elections commission office and Chinese temple were attacked. The culprits were never caught.
Looking at the slate of candidates, the upcoming West Kalimantan poll, involving almost 3.5 million voters, is also expected to be a highly charged race.
Ms Karolin and her running mate, backed by the Indonesian Democratic Party-Struggle and the Democratic Party, are both Christians but have deep connections to the Dayak communities across Kalimantan.
Their main rivals are the Muslim pairing of Pontianak Mayor Sutardmidji and Mempawah regent Ria Norsan, who are backed by Golkar, Hanura and other Islamic parties.

Also contesting is a mixed Christian-Muslim team comprising former Sintang regent Milton Crosby and National Mandate Party local cadre member Boyman Harun. Although backed by Indonesia's largest opposition party, Gerindra, Mr Milton, who is a Christian Dayak, and Mr Boyman, a Malay Muslim, are not expected to win, but could split the Dayak vote for the Karolin-Suryadman joint ticket.

Identity politics has always been a major issue during elections in West Kalimantan due to its long history of ethnic violence, said Ms Dian Lestari, who chairs the local chapter of the Alliance of Independent Journalists in Pontianak.

"Between 1960 and 1999, there were at least 11 instances of such conflict," she told The Straits Times last week. Ms Dian was referring to clashes between Dayak militias and Muslim Madurese migrants in the late 1990s that led to the deaths of hundreds, possibly thousands, of Madurese.
The violence resulted in ethnic gerrymandering across Kalimantan in a bid to prevent further conflict.

Mr Deka believes that the potential for violence this time around will depend a lot on how the candidates run their campaigns in a province where ethnicity and religion are critical factors in mobilising electoral support.
"It will be up to the candidates to ensure that the polarisation left over from the anti-Ahok campaign does not produce communal clashes," said Mr Deka.
Ms Dian, who also warned about the threat of fake news online, agreed, adding that the local police are now "being very watchful" despite the calm on the surface.
